Summary: SC for 6.3.25. Limited and thawing snow cover. Stable throughout, greatest amounts on NW,N,NE aspects abv 900. Hazard Low
SnowDistribution: Limited patchy snow in specific places.  Cloud base was at 700m or so through the day.  Winds approx 60- 75 mph, serious conditions.
Comment: Remaining very mild but cooler by Friday.
WeatherInfluences: Gale to storm force South-Westerly winds will continue throughout the forecast period. Freezing levels will be well above the summits. Rainfall to all levels, will be persistent through the day but easing to light in the afternoon.
SnowStability: Snow cover will continue to diminish further in the rain and warmer temperatures but will be well bonded and stable throughout. Greatest amounts will be above 900m,  limited in extent and restricted to coire back walls and gullies on North-West to North-East aspects. Elsewhere, small patches remain in wind sheltered places and terrain will be largely bare of snow. The avalanche hazard will be Low
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Very strong gale to storm force South-Westerly winds with rainfall. Freezing level well above the summits
ObservedSnowStability: Snow cover continues to diminish but the snowpack is stable throughout. Greatest amounts are above 900m and restricted to coire back walls, coire rims and gullies on North-West to North-East aspects. Elsewhere, terrain is mostly bare of snow.  The avalanche hazard is Low

Summary: CM for 6.3 Snowpack thawing at all levels. Stability generally good. Remaining cornices mainly above steep N-E-SE aspects. Haz Low
SnowDistribution: Diminishing snowpack. Cloud base around 800-900m.  Winds 40-50 mph at higher levels.
WeatherInfluences: The freezing level will remain above all summits. Overnight there will be a period of rain at all levels, thereafter the day is expected to be dry. Winds will be storm force South-Westerly during the evening, then backing and easing a little to be gale force Southerly during the day.
SnowStability: The snowpack will continue to thaw at all levels and stability will generally be good. Remaining cornices, present mainly above steep North through East to South-East aspects, will still be suspect though the threat of spontaneous collapse is diminishing. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Rain at all levels; heavier and persistent overnight and light during the day. The freezing level was well above all summits. Winds were very strong South-Westerly.
ObservedSnowStability: The diminishing snowpack is thawing at all levels and stability is generally good at all levels and on all aspects. Greatest accumulations are on North to East aspects. Cornices remain mainly above steep North through East to South-East aspects. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: TO for 06/03 Heavy rain overnight, dry Thurs. Gale force SSW winds. Freezing above tops. Continued snow loss. Hazard Low.
Comment:
There has been significant snow loss over the last 24 hours of the already patchy snowpack. This will continue, and, as stated yesterday, there will be little if any snow left in the Torridon forecast area.
Looking ahead, Friday is generally settled but remains warm, the weekend is mixed, with the best weather most likely on Sunday. It does look like we will return to colder conditions on the hills early next week.
WeatherInfluences: Overnight heavy rain, to all levels, will ease by Thursday morning. Then, through the day on Thursday it will be largely dry and cloudy.  Winds will remain South-South-Westerly Gale force on the tops. Although the freezing level will lower slightly, it will remain well above the summits throughout the period.
SnowStability: The remnants of snow remaining, on North to East aspects above 900 metres, will continue to thaw and diminish, and will remain stable and well bonded. These scattered patches will only be encountered at the highest elevations on Coire rims and gully tops. In general the hills are largely snow free. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Occasional light rain throughout the day. The winds were Storm force South-Westerlies, even at moderate elevations. Freezing level was well above the summits, with 9 degrees Celsius being recorded at 550 metres.
ObservedSnowStability:
Only small, scattered remnants of snow remain, in isolated locations, on North to East aspects over 850 metres. What little is left is stable and continues to thaw rapidly in the wet and mild conditions. 
The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: LO for 6/3. Mild. Wet patchy snow continues to thaw. Generally stable. Any remaining cornices prone to collapse. Low Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Wet snow throughout. Poor Visibility.  Winds approx 60- 75 mph.
Comment: Very poor visibility the past couple of days, hopefully improving tomorrow.
WeatherInfluences: After some overnight rain it will be a generally dry day. Gale force winds will be from the South. The freezing level will remain above the summits.
SnowStability: The patchy wet spring snowpack will continue to thaw and consolidate. Stability will remain generally good throughout. However, any remaining sections of cornice will continue to slump and will be prone to collapse. The avalanche hazard will be Low
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A warm windy day with spells of drizzly rain. The freezing level was well above the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: The wet spring snowpack continues to thaw and consolidate. The greatest deposits remain in gullies and coires with North-West through North to East aspects above 1000 metres. Stability is generally good. However, remaining sections of cornice are slumping and prone to collapse. The avalanche hazard is Low

Summary: GC6/3 Rain PM drier AM mild. Isolated weak cornices possible N-E slopes 1000m+ snowpack gen stable Avalanche Hazard Low.
SnowDistribution: Wet snow throughout.  Very poor visibility throughout the day above 500 metres . Winds 30-40 mph much stronger on summits.
WeatherInfluences: Conditions will remain  mild with persistent heavy rain at all levels overnight becoming mainly dry through the day. Winds will be strong occasionally gale force generally Southerly. The freezing level will be around 2000 metres.
SnowStability: The mild and wet conditions overnight will maintain the soft and moist snowpack at all levels, stability will be generally good but shallow surface wet snow instabilities may exist initially on the steepest slopes. Isolated fragile cornices may exist mainly above 1000 metres.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Mild and windy conditions with persistent rain at all levels have affected the area, the freezing level is well above the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: Mild conditions with rain at all levels have reduced the snow cover in all areas. Greatest accumulations of snow exist in the higher Northerly and Easterly corries and gulleys. The remaining snowpack is generally soft and moist at levels. Stability is generally good. Small cornices exist in localised areas mainly above 1000 metres on North-East and Easterly aspects.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: 0603 for NC Diminishing snow cover with greatest amounts found above 1000m on N to E aspects with good stability.  Low Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Diminishing snowpack, greatest amounts above 1000 metres.  Good visibility.  Summit winds approx 75 mph and above.
Comment: Threat of falling rock and ice remains during the thaw.  Remaining mild for the time being before early indications of cold North Easterlies developing at the start of next week.
WeatherInfluences: A mostly dry forecast and remaining mild with the freezing level above the summits.  Storm force winds, initially from the South-West before backing South during the day.
SnowStability: The remaining snow cover will continue to diminish in the mild conditions and will have good stability throughout.  Greatest amounts will be found on North to East aspects above 1000 metres, predominately around coire rims and headwalls, gully tops, ridge flanks and high plateaus. Little snow will be found below this altitude.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: It was a dry morning with some light drizzle during the afternoon.  Storm force South-Westerly winds with the freezing level above the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: The remaining stable snow patches continue to diminish in the mild conditions.  Greatest amounts are found above 1000 metres on North to East aspects mainly around coire rims and back walls, gully tops and on the plateau.  Very little snow remains below this altitude.  The avalanche hazard is Low.
